scene.title: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter Second French Lord, with five or six other Soldiers in ambush

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: He can come no other way but by this hedge-corner.
When you sally upon him, speak what terrible
language you will: though you understand it not
yourselves, no matter; for we must not seem to
understand him, unless some one among us whom we
must produce for an interpreter.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: Good captain, let me be the interpreter.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: Art not acquainted with him? knows he not thy voice?

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: No, sir, I warrant you.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: But what linsey-woolsey hast thou to speak to us again?

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: E'en such as you speak to me.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: He must think us some band of strangers i' the
adversary's entertainment. Now he hath a smack of
all neighbouring languages; therefore we must every
one be a man of his own fancy, not to know what we
speak one to another; so we seem to know, is to
know straight our purpose: choughs' language,
gabble enough, and good enough. As for you,
interpreter, you must seem very politic. But couch,
ho! here he comes, to beguile two hours in a sleep,
and then to return and swear the lies he forges.

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: Ten o'clock: within these three hours 'twill be
time enough to go home. What shall I say I have
done? It must be a very plausive invention that
carries it: they begin to smoke me; and disgraces
have of late knocked too often at my door. I find
my tongue is too foolhardy; but my heart hath the
fear of Mars before it and of his creatures, not
daring the reports of my tongue.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: This is the first truth that e'er thine own tongue
was guilty of.

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: What the devil should move me to undertake the
recovery of this drum, being not ignorant of the
impossibility, and knowing I had no such purpose? I
must give myself some hurts, and say I got them in
exploit: yet slight ones will not carry it; they
will say, 'Came you off with so little?' and great
ones I dare not give. Wherefore, what's the
instance? Tongue, I must put you into a
butter-woman's mouth and buy myself another of
Bajazet's mule, if you prattle me into these perils.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: Is it possible he should know what he is, and be
that he is?

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: I would the cutting of my garments would serve the
turn, or the breaking of my Spanish sword.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: We cannot afford you so.

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: Or the baring of my beard; and to say it was in
stratagem.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: 'Twould not do.

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: Or to drown my clothes, and say I was stripped.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: Hardly serve.

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: Though I swore I leaped from the window of the citadel.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: How deep?

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: Thirty fathom.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: Three great oaths would scarce make that be believed.

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: I would I had any drum of the enemy's: I would swear
I recovered it.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: You shall hear one anon.

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: A drum now of the enemy's,--

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: Throca movousus, cargo, cargo, cargo.

speech.speaker: All
speech.line: Cargo, cargo, cargo, villiando par corbo, cargo.

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: O, ransom, ransom! do not hide mine eyes.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: Boskos thromuldo boskos.

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: I know you are the Muskos' regiment:
And I shall lose my life for want of language;
If there be here German, or Dane, low Dutch,
Italian, or French, let him speak to me; I'll
Discover that which shall undo the Florentine.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: Boskos vauvado: I understand thee, and can speak
thy tongue. Kerely bonto, sir, betake thee to thy
faith, for seventeen poniards are at thy bosom.

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: O!

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: O, pray, pray, pray! Manka revania dulche.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: Oscorbidulchos volivorco.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: The general is content to spare thee yet;
And, hoodwink'd as thou art, will lead thee on
To gather from thee: haply thou mayst inform
Something to save thy life.

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: O, let me live!
And all the secrets of our camp I'll show,
Their force, their purposes; nay, I'll speak that
Which you will wonder at.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: But wilt thou faithfully?

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: If I do not, damn me.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: Acordo linta.
Come on; thou art granted space.

scene-body.stagedir: Exit, with PAROLLES guarded. A short alarum within

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: Go, tell the Count Rousillon, and my brother,
We have caught the woodcock, and will keep him muffled
Till we do hear from them.

speech.speaker: Second Soldier
speech.line: Captain, I will.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: A' will betray us all unto ourselves:
Inform on that.

speech.speaker: Second Soldier
speech.line: So I will, sir.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: Till then I'll keep him dark and safely lock'd.

scene.title: SCENE II. Florence. The Widow's house.

speech.speaker: BERTRAM
speech.line: They told me that your name was Fontibell.

speech.speaker: DIANA
speech.line: No, my good lord, Diana.

speech.speaker: BERTRAM
speech.line: Titled goddess;
And worth it, with addition! But, fair soul,
In your fine frame hath love no quality?
If quick fire of youth light not your mind,
You are no maiden, but a monument:
When you are dead, you should be such a one
As you are now, for you are cold and stem;
And now you should be as your mother was
When your sweet self was got.

speech.speaker: DIANA
speech.line: She then was honest.

speech.speaker: BERTRAM
speech.line: So should you be.

speech.speaker: DIANA
speech.line: No:
My mother did but duty; such, my lord,
As you owe to your wife.

speech.speaker: BERTRAM
speech.line: No more o' that;
I prithee, do not strive against my vows:
I was compell'd to her; but I love thee
By love's own sweet constraint, and will for ever
Do thee all rights of service.

speech.speaker: DIANA
speech.line: Ay, so you serve us
Till we serve you; but when you have our roses,
You barely leave our thorns to prick ourselves
And mock us with our bareness.

speech.speaker: BERTRAM
speech.line: How have I sworn!

speech.speaker: DIANA
speech.line: 'Tis not the many oaths that makes the truth,
But the plain single vow that is vow'd true.
What is not holy, that we swear not by,
But take the High'st to witness: then, pray you, tell me,
If I should swear by God's great attributes,
I loved you dearly, would you believe my oaths,
When I did love you ill? This has no holding,
To swear by him whom I protest to love,
That I will work against him: therefore your oaths
Are words and poor conditions, but unseal'd,
At least in my opinion.

speech.speaker: BERTRAM
speech.line: Change it, change it;
Be not so holy-cruel: love is holy;
And my integrity ne'er knew the crafts
That you do charge men with. Stand no more off,
But give thyself unto my sick desires,
Who then recover: say thou art mine, and ever
My love as it begins shall so persever.

speech.speaker: DIANA
speech.line: I see that men make ropes in such a scarre
That we'll forsake ourselves. Give me that ring.

speech.speaker: BERTRAM
speech.line: I'll lend it thee, my dear; but have no power
To give it from me.

speech.speaker: DIANA
speech.line: Will you not, my lord?

speech.speaker: BERTRAM
speech.line: It is an honour 'longing to our house,
Bequeathed down from many ancestors;
Which were the greatest obloquy i' the world
In me to lose.

speech.speaker: DIANA
speech.line: Mine honour's such a ring:
My chastity's the jewel of our house,
Bequeathed down from many ancestors;
Which were the greatest obloquy i' the world
In me to lose: thus your own proper wisdom
Brings in the champion Honour on my part,
Against your vain assault.

speech.speaker: BERTRAM
speech.line: Here, take my ring:
My house, mine honour, yea, my life, be thine,
And I'll be bid by thee.

speech.speaker: DIANA
speech.line: When midnight comes, knock at my chamber-window:
I'll order take my mother shall not hear.
Now will I charge you in the band of truth,
When you have conquer'd my yet maiden bed,
Remain there but an hour, nor speak to me:
My reasons are most strong; and you shall know them
When back again this ring shall be deliver'd:
And on your finger in the night I'll put
Another ring, that what in time proceeds
May token to the future our past deeds.
Adieu, till then; then, fail not. You have won
A wife of me, though there my hope be done.

speech.speaker: BERTRAM
speech.line: A heaven on earth I have won by wooing thee.

speech.speaker: DIANA
speech.line: For which live long to thank both heaven and me!
You may so in the end.
My mother told me just how he would woo,
As if she sat in 's heart; she says all men
Have the like oaths: he had sworn to marry me
When his wife's dead; therefore I'll lie with him
When I am buried. Since Frenchmen are so braid,
Marry that will, I live and die a maid:
Only in this disguise I think't no sin
To cozen him that would unjustly win.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: You have not given him his mother's letter?

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: I have delivered it an hour since: there is
something in't that stings his nature; for on the
reading it he changed almost into another man.

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: He has much worthy blame laid upon him for shaking
off so good a wife and so sweet a lady.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: Especially he hath incurred the everlasting
displeasure of the king, who had even tuned his
bounty to sing happiness to him. I will tell you a
thing, but you shall let it dwell darkly with you.

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: When you have spoken it, 'tis dead, and I am the
grave of it.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: He hath perverted a young gentlewoman here in
Florence, of a most chaste renown; and this night he
fleshes his will in the spoil of her honour: he hath
given her his monumental ring, and thinks himself
made in the unchaste composition.

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: Now, God delay our rebellion! as we are ourselves,
what things are we!

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: Merely our own traitors. And as in the common course
of all treasons, we still see them reveal
themselves, till they attain to their abhorred ends,
so he that in this action contrives against his own
nobility, in his proper stream o'erflows himself.

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: Is it not meant damnable in us, to be trumpeters of
our unlawful intents? We shall not then have his
company to-night?

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: Not till after midnight; for he is dieted to his hour.

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: That approaches apace; I would gladly have him see
his company anatomized, that he might take a measure
of his own judgments, wherein so curiously he had
set this counterfeit.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: We will not meddle with him till he come; for his
presence must be the whip of the other.

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: In the mean time, what hear you of these wars?

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: I hear there is an overture of peace.

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: Nay, I assure you, a peace concluded.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: What will Count Rousillon do then? will he travel
higher, or return again into France?

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: I perceive, by this demand, you are not altogether
of his council.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: Let it be forbid, sir; so should I be a great deal
of his act.

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: Sir, his wife some two months since fled from his
house: her pretence is a pilgrimage to Saint Jaques
le Grand; which holy undertaking with most austere
sanctimony she accomplished; and, there residing the
tenderness of her nature became as a prey to her
grief; in fine, made a groan of her last breath, and
now she sings in heaven.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: How is this justified?

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: The stronger part of it by her own letters, which
makes her story true, even to the point of her
death: her death itself, which could not be her
office to say is come, was faithfully confirmed by
the rector of the place.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: Hath the count all this intelligence?

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: Ay, and the particular confirmations, point from
point, so to the full arming of the verity.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: I am heartily sorry that he'll be glad of this.

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: How mightily sometimes we make us comforts of our losses!

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: And how mightily some other times we drown our gain
in tears! The great dignity that his valour hath
here acquired for him shall at home be encountered
with a shame as ample.

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: The web of our life is of a mingled yarn, good and
ill together: our virtues would be proud, if our
faults whipped them not; and our crimes would
despair, if they were not cherished by our virtues.
How now! where's your master?

speech.speaker: Servant
speech.line: He met the duke in the street, sir, of whom he hath
taken a solemn leave: his lordship will next
morning for France. The duke hath offered him
letters of commendations to the king.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: They shall be no more than needful there, if they
were more than they can commend.

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: They cannot be too sweet for the king's tartness.
Here's his lordship now.
How now, my lord! is't not after midnight?

speech.speaker: BERTRAM
speech.line: I have to-night dispatched sixteen businesses, a
month's length a-piece, by an abstract of success:
I have congied with the duke, done my adieu with his
nearest; buried a wife, mourned for her; writ to my
lady mother I am returning; entertained my convoy;
and between these main parcels of dispatch effected
many nicer needs; the last was the greatest, but
that I have not ended yet.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: If the business be of any difficulty, and this
morning your departure hence, it requires haste of
your lordship.

speech.speaker: BERTRAM
speech.line: I mean, the business is not ended, as fearing to
hear of it hereafter. But shall we have this
dialogue between the fool and the soldier? Come,
bring forth this counterfeit module, he has deceived
me, like a double-meaning prophesier.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: Bring him forth: has sat i' the stocks all night,
poor gallant knave.

speech.speaker: BERTRAM
speech.line: No matter: his heels have deserved it, in usurping
his spurs so long. How does he carry himself?

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: I have told your lordship already, the stocks carry
him. But to answer you as you would be understood;
he weeps like a wench that had shed her milk: he
hath confessed himself to Morgan, whom he supposes
to be a friar, from the time of his remembrance to
this very instant disaster of his setting i' the
stocks: and what think you he hath confessed?

speech.speaker: BERTRAM
speech.line: Nothing of me, has a'?

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: His confession is taken, and it shall be read to his
face: if your lordship be in't, as I believe you
are, you must have the patience to hear it.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier

speech.speaker: BERTRAM
speech.line: A plague upon him! muffled! he can say nothing of
me: hush, hush!

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: Hoodman comes! Portotartarosa

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: He calls for the tortures: what will you say
without 'em?

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: I will confess what I know without constraint: if
ye pinch me like a pasty, I can say no more.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: Bosko chimurcho.

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: Boblibindo chicurmurco.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: You are a merciful general. Our general bids you
answer to what I shall ask you out of a note.

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: And truly, as I hope to live.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: Reads 'First demand of him how many horse the
duke is strong.' What say you to that?

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: Five or six thousand; but very weak and
unserviceable: the troops are all scattered, and
the commanders very poor rogues, upon my reputation
and credit and as I hope to live.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: Shall I set down your answer so?

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: Do: I'll take the sacrament on't, how and which way you will.

speech.speaker: BERTRAM
speech.line: All's one to him. What a past-saving slave is this!

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: You're deceived, my lord: this is Monsieur
Parolles, the gallant militarist,--that was his own
phrase,--that had the whole theoric of war in the
knot of his scarf, and the practise in the chape of
his dagger.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: I will never trust a man again for keeping his sword
clean. nor believe he can have every thing in him
by wearing his apparel neatly.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: Well, that's set down.

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: Five or six thousand horse, I said,-- I will say
true,--or thereabouts, set down, for I'll speak truth.

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: He's very near the truth in this.

speech.speaker: BERTRAM
speech.line: But I con him no thanks for't, in the nature he
delivers it.

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: Poor rogues, I pray you, say.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: Well, that's set down.

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: I humbly thank you, sir: a truth's a truth, the
rogues are marvellous poor.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: Reads 'Demand of him, of what strength they are
a-foot.' What say you to that?

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: By my troth, sir, if I were to live this present
hour, I will tell true. Let me see: Spurio, a
hundred and fifty; Sebastian, so many; Corambus, so
many; Jaques, so many; Guiltian, Cosmo, Lodowick,
and Gratii, two hundred and fifty each; mine own
company, Chitopher, Vaumond, Bentii, two hundred and
fifty each: so that the muster-file, rotten and
sound, upon my life, amounts not to fifteen thousand
poll; half of the which dare not shake snow from off
their cassocks, lest they shake themselves to pieces.

speech.speaker: BERTRAM
speech.line: What shall be done to him?

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: Nothing, but let him have thanks. Demand of him my
condition, and what credit I have with the duke.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: Well, that's set down.
'You shall demand of him, whether one Captain Dumain
be i' the camp, a Frenchman; what his reputation is
with the duke; what his valour, honesty, and
expertness in wars; or whether he thinks it were not
possible, with well-weighing sums of gold, to
corrupt him to revolt.' What say you to this? what
do you know of it?

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: I beseech you, let me answer to the particular of
the inter'gatories: demand them singly.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: Do you know this Captain Dumain?

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: I know him: a' was a botcher's 'prentice in Paris,
from whence he was whipped for getting the shrieve's
fool with child,--a dumb innocent, that could not
say him nay.

speech.speaker: BERTRAM
speech.line: Nay, by your leave, hold your hands; though I know
his brains are forfeit to the next tile that falls.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: Well, is this captain in the duke of Florence's camp?

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: Upon my knowledge, he is, and lousy.

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: Nay look not so upon me; we shall hear of your
lordship anon.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: What is his reputation with the duke?

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: The duke knows him for no other but a poor officer
of mine; and writ to me this other day to turn him
out o' the band: I think I have his letter in my pocket.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: Marry, we'll search.

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: In good sadness, I do not know; either it is there,
or it is upon a file with the duke's other letters
in my tent.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: Here 'tis; here's a paper: shall I read it to you?

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: I do not know if it be it or no.

speech.speaker: BERTRAM
speech.line: Our interpreter does it well.

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: Excellently.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: Reads 'Dian, the count's a fool, and full of gold,'--

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: That is not the duke's letter, sir; that is an
advertisement to a proper maid in Florence, one
Diana, to take heed of the allurement of one Count
Rousillon, a foolish idle boy, but for all that very
ruttish: I pray you, sir, put it up again.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: Nay, I'll read it first, by your favour.

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: My meaning in't, I protest, was very honest in the
behalf of the maid; for I knew the young count to be
a dangerous and lascivious boy, who is a whale to
virginity and devours up all the fry it finds.

speech.speaker: BERTRAM
speech.line: Damnable both-sides rogue!

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: Reads 'When he swears oaths, bid him drop gold, and take it;
After he scores, he never pays the score:
Half won is match well made; match, and well make it;
He ne'er pays after-debts, take it before;
And say a soldier, Dian, told thee this,
Men are to mell with, boys are not to kiss:
For count of this, the count's a fool, I know it,
Who pays before, but not when he does owe it.
Thine, as he vowed to thee in thine ear,
PAROLLES.'

speech.speaker: BERTRAM
speech.line: He shall be whipped through the army with this rhyme
in's forehead.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: This is your devoted friend, sir, the manifold
linguist and the armipotent soldier.

speech.speaker: BERTRAM
speech.line: I could endure any thing before but a cat, and now
he's a cat to me.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: I perceive, sir, by the general's looks, we shall be
fain to hang you.

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: My life, sir, in any case: not that I am afraid to
die; but that, my offences being many, I would
repent out the remainder of nature: let me live,
sir, in a dungeon, i' the stocks, or any where, so I may live.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: We'll see what may be done, so you confess freely;
therefore, once more to this Captain Dumain: you
have answered to his reputation with the duke and to
his valour: what is his honesty?

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: He will steal, sir, an egg out of a cloister: for
rapes and ravishments he parallels Nessus: he
professes not keeping of oaths; in breaking 'em he
is stronger than Hercules: he will lie, sir, with
such volubility, that you would think truth were a
fool: drunkenness is his best virtue, for he will
be swine-drunk; and in his sleep he does little
harm, save to his bed-clothes about him; but they
know his conditions and lay him in straw. I have but
little more to say, sir, of his honesty: he has
every thing that an honest man should not have; what
an honest man should have, he has nothing.

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: I begin to love him for this.

speech.speaker: BERTRAM
speech.line: For this description of thine honesty? A pox upon
him for me, he's more and more a cat.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: What say you to his expertness in war?

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: Faith, sir, he has led the drum before the English
tragedians; to belie him, I will not, and more of
his soldiership I know not; except, in that country
he had the honour to be the officer at a place there
called Mile-end, to instruct for the doubling of
files: I would do the man what honour I can, but of
this I am not certain.

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: He hath out-villained villany so far, that the
rarity redeems him.

speech.speaker: BERTRAM
speech.line: A pox on him, he's a cat still.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: His qualities being at this poor price, I need not
to ask you if gold will corrupt him to revolt.

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: Sir, for a quart d'ecu he will sell the fee-simple
of his salvation, the inheritance of it; and cut the
entail from all remainders, and a perpetual
succession for it perpetually.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: What's his brother, the other Captain Dumain?

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: Why does be ask him of me?

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: What's he?

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: E'en a crow o' the same nest; not altogether so
great as the first in goodness, but greater a great
deal in evil: he excels his brother for a coward,
yet his brother is reputed one of the best that is:
in a retreat he outruns any lackey; marry, in coming
on he has the cramp.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: If your life be saved, will you undertake to betray
the Florentine?

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: Ay, and the captain of his horse, Count Rousillon.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: I'll whisper with the general, and know his pleasure.

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: Aside I'll no more drumming; a plague of all
drums! Only to seem to deserve well, and to
beguile the supposition of that lascivious young boy
the count, have I run into this danger. Yet who
would have suspected an ambush where I was taken?

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: There is no remedy, sir, but you must die: the
general says, you that have so traitorously
discovered the secrets of your army and made such
pestiferous reports of men very nobly held, can
serve the world for no honest use; therefore you
must die. Come, headsman, off with his head.

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: O Lord, sir, let me live, or let me see my death!

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: That shall you, and take your leave of all your friends.
So, look about you: know you any here?

speech.speaker: BERTRAM
speech.line: Good morrow, noble captain.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: God bless you, Captain Parolles.

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: God save you, noble captain.

speech.speaker: Second Lord
speech.line: Captain, what greeting will you to my Lord Lafeu?
I am for France.

speech.speaker: First Lord
speech.line: Good captain, will you give me a copy of the sonnet
you writ to Diana in behalf of the Count Rousillon?
an I were not a very coward, I'ld compel it of you:
but fare you well.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: You are undone, captain, all but your scarf; that
has a knot on't yet

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: Who cannot be crushed with a plot?

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: If you could find out a country where but women were
that had received so much shame, you might begin an
impudent nation. Fare ye well, sir; I am for France
too: we shall speak of you there.

speech.speaker: PAROLLES
speech.line: Yet am I thankful: if my heart were great,
'Twould burst at this. Captain I'll be no more;
But I will eat and drink, and sleep as soft
As captain shall: simply the thing I am
Shall make me live. Who knows himself a braggart,
Let him fear this, for it will come to pass
that every braggart shall be found an ass.
Rust, sword? cool, blushes! and, Parolles, live
Safest in shame! being fool'd, by foolery thrive!
There's place and means for every man alive.
I'll after them.

scene.title: SCENE IV. Florence. The Widow's house.

speech.speaker: HELENA
speech.line: That you may well perceive I have not wrong'd you,
One of the greatest in the Christian world
Shall be my surety; 'fore whose throne 'tis needful,
Ere I can perfect mine intents, to kneel:
Time was, I did him a desired office,
Dear almost as his life; which gratitude
Through flinty Tartar's bosom would peep forth,
And answer, thanks: I duly am inform'd
His grace is at Marseilles; to which place
We have convenient convoy. You must know
I am supposed dead: the army breaking,
My husband hies him home; where, heaven aiding,
And by the leave of my good lord the king,
We'll be before our welcome.

speech.speaker: Widow
speech.line: Gentle madam,
You never had a servant to whose trust
Your business was more welcome.

speech.speaker: HELENA
speech.line: Nor you, mistress,
Ever a friend whose thoughts more truly labour
To recompense your love: doubt not but heaven
Hath brought me up to be your daughter's dower,
As it hath fated her to be my motive
And helper to a husband. But, O strange men!
That can such sweet use make of what they hate,
When saucy trusting of the cozen'd thoughts
Defiles the pitchy night: so lust doth play
With what it loathes for that which is away.
But more of this hereafter. You, Diana,
Under my poor instructions yet must suffer
Something in my behalf.

speech.speaker: DIANA
speech.line: Let death and honesty
Go with your impositions, I am yours
Upon your will to suffer.

speech.speaker: HELENA
speech.line: Yet, I pray you:
But with the word the time will bring on summer,
When briers shall have leaves as well as thorns,
And be as sweet as sharp. We must away;
Our wagon is prepared, and time revives us:
All's well that ends well; still the fine's the crown;
Whate'er the course, the end is the renown.

scene.title: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.

speech.speaker: LAFEU
speech.line: No, no, no, your son was misled with a snipt-taffeta
fellow there, whose villanous saffron would have
made all the unbaked and doughy youth of a nation in
his colour: your daughter-in-law had been alive at
this hour, and your son here at home, more advanced
by the king than by that red-tailed humble-bee I speak of.

speech.speaker: COUNTESS
speech.line: I would I had not known him; it was the death of the
most virtuous gentlewoman that ever nature had
praise for creating. If she had partaken of my
flesh, and cost me the dearest groans of a mother, I
could not have owed her a more rooted love.

speech.speaker: LAFEU
speech.line: 'Twas a good lady, 'twas a good lady: we may pick a
thousand salads ere we light on such another herb.

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: Indeed, sir, she was the sweet marjoram of the
salad, or rather, the herb of grace.

speech.speaker: LAFEU
speech.line: They are not herbs, you knave; they are nose-herbs.

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: I am no great Nebuchadnezzar, sir; I have not much
skill in grass.

speech.speaker: LAFEU
speech.line: Whether dost thou profess thyself, a knave or a fool?

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: A fool, sir, at a woman's service, and a knave at a man's.

speech.speaker: LAFEU
speech.line: Your distinction?

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: I would cozen the man of his wife and do his service.

speech.speaker: LAFEU
speech.line: So you were a knave at his service, indeed.

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: And I would give his wife my bauble, sir, to do her service.

speech.speaker: LAFEU
speech.line: I will subscribe for thee, thou art both knave and fool.

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: At your service.

speech.speaker: LAFEU
speech.line: No, no, no.

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: Why, sir, if I cannot serve you, I can serve as
great a prince as you are.

speech.speaker: LAFEU
speech.line: Who's that? a Frenchman?

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: Faith, sir, a' has an English name; but his fisnomy
is more hotter in France than there.

speech.speaker: LAFEU
speech.line: What prince is that?

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: The black prince, sir; alias, the prince of
darkness; alias, the devil.

speech.speaker: LAFEU
speech.line: Hold thee, there's my purse: I give thee not this
to suggest thee from thy master thou talkest of;
serve him still.

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: I am a woodland fellow, sir, that always loved a
great fire; and the master I speak of ever keeps a
good fire. But, sure, he is the prince of the
world; let his nobility remain in's court. I am for
the house with the narrow gate, which I take to be
too little for pomp to enter: some that humble
themselves may; but the many will be too chill and
tender, and they'll be for the flowery way that
leads to the broad gate and the great fire.

speech.speaker: LAFEU
speech.line: Go thy ways, I begin to be aweary of thee; and I
tell thee so before, because I would not fall out
with thee. Go thy ways: let my horses be well
looked to, without any tricks.

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: If I put any tricks upon 'em, sir, they shall be
jades' tricks; which are their own right by the law of nature.

speech.speaker: LAFEU
speech.line: A shrewd knave and an unhappy.

speech.speaker: COUNTESS
speech.line: So he is. My lord that's gone made himself much
sport out of him: by his authority he remains here,
which he thinks is a patent for his sauciness; and,
indeed, he has no pace, but runs where he will.

speech.speaker: LAFEU
speech.line: I like him well; 'tis not amiss. And I was about to
tell you, since I heard of the good lady's death and
that my lord your son was upon his return home, I
moved the king my master to speak in the behalf of
my daughter; which, in the minority of them both,
his majesty, out of a self-gracious remembrance, did
first propose: his highness hath promised me to do
it: and, to stop up the displeasure he hath
conceived against your son, there is no fitter
matter. How does your ladyship like it?

speech.speaker: COUNTESS
speech.line: With very much content, my lord; and I wish it
happily effected.

speech.speaker: LAFEU
speech.line: His highness comes post from Marseilles, of as able
body as when he numbered thirty: he will be here
to-morrow, or I am deceived by him that in such
intelligence hath seldom failed.

speech.speaker: COUNTESS
speech.line: It rejoices me, that I hope I shall see him ere I
die. I have letters that my son will be here
to-night: I shall beseech your lordship to remain
with me till they meet together.

speech.speaker: LAFEU
speech.line: Madam, I was thinking with what manners I might
safely be admitted.

speech.speaker: COUNTESS
speech.line: You need but plead your honourable privilege.

speech.speaker: LAFEU
speech.line: Lady, of that I have made a bold charter; but I
thank my God it holds yet.

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: O madam, yonder's my lord your son with a patch of
velvet on's face: whether there be a scar under't
or no, the velvet knows; but 'tis a goodly patch of
velvet: his left cheek is a cheek of two pile and a
half, but his right cheek is worn bare.

speech.speaker: LAFEU
speech.line: A scar nobly got, or a noble scar, is a good livery
of honour; so belike is that.

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: But it is your carbonadoed face.

speech.speaker: LAFEU
speech.line: Let us go see your son, I pray you: I long to talk
with the young noble soldier.

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: Faith there's a dozen of 'em, with delicate fine
hats and most courteous feathers, which bow the head
and nod at every man.
